Description: The European Studies Minor allows students to develop an interdisciplinary background in the histories, languages, cultures, and political and economic systems of Europe. Students will be exposed to a wide variety of courses that address the historical development of Europe, its contemporary importance in the globalized world, and its many rich cultural traditions. The minor is a useful complement for students in a wide variety of majors, including Anthropology, Art History, Communication, History, International Studies, Languages, Philosophy, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Sociology. It can also provide a solid foundation for students interested in careers in government, journalism, international business, and graduate studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, examples include $500, $1,000, up to full cost of attendance

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science program prepares students to work in various health and wellness settings, including corporate wellness, community health, cardiac rehabilitation, and strength and conditioning. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in human anatomy and physiology, biomechanics, exercise physiology, and exercise testing and prescription. Students also gain practical experience through internships and research opportunities. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for entry-level positions in the exercise science field or for further graduate study in areas such as physical therapy, occupational therapy, and chiropractic. Upon completion of the Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science program, students will be able to: Describe the anatomical, physiological, and biomechanical responses and adaptations to exercise. Conduct various fitness assessments and interpret the results. Design and implement safe and effective exercise programs for diverse populations. Understand the ethical and professional responsibilities in the field of exercise science. Communicate effectively both orally and in writing regarding exercise science concepts.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; e.g., Chancellor's Scholarship is $3,000/year, Crown Scholars Program is $5,000/year

Requirements: To be considered for admission, you must meet the minimum course requirements (MCR) as established by the UNC Board of Governors. At UNC Charlotte, we are looking for a comprehensive and challenging curriculum, so students who take more than the minimum required courses will be more competitive. Minimum Course Requirements: 4 units of English; 4 units of Math (including algebra I, geometry, algebra II, and a fourth-level math course beyond algebra II); 3 units of Science (including at least one life science, at least one physical science, and at least one lab); 2 units of Social Science (including one unit of U.S. history); 2 units of the same Foreign Language; 1 unit of an Academic Elective.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Finance provides students with a strong theoretical and practical foundation in financial management, investments, and financial markets and institutions. The program is designed to develop problem-solving and decision-making skills required for success in a diverse and dynamic financial environment. Students will gain an understanding of financial principles, analytical tools, and ethical considerations relevant to various finance careers. Through a comprehensive curriculum, students learn to analyze financial data, evaluate investment opportunities, manage financial risk, and make informed financial decisions in both corporate and personal contexts.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $500 to the full cost of attendance

Description: The Finance Minor is designed for students outside of the Belk College of Business who wish to expand their knowledge of financial concepts. The minor consists of 15 credit hours requiring a minimum grade of C in each course. Students must complete FINN 2120 and FINN 3120 plus 9 credit hours of 3000-4000 level Finance courses. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 is required in all courses counting toward the minor. Admission to the minor requires a cumulative GPA of 2.5 overall, a C or better in ACCT 2121 and MATH 1120 or MATH 1241 or MATH 1242 or MATH 1340 or MATH 1342. Students should consult the Belk College of Business academic advisor for minor admission requirements. The Minor in Finance does not have any concentrations.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $317.67/credit hour (tuition only); Out-of-State: $1511.33/credit hour (tuition only) (2024-2025)

ProgramName: Minor in Fire and Emergency Management
Requirements: Minors may be declared by current UNC Charlotte undergraduate students at any time after they have earned 12 or more credit hours at UNC Charlotte. To declare a minor, students should use the online academic plan/minor declaration system.

Description: The Foreign Language Education minor prepares students to teach a foreign language (American Sign Language, Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Latin, or Spanish) in grades K-12. This program of study is offered through the Department of Languages and Culture Studies in the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences and the Department of Middle, Secondary, and K-12 Education in the Cato College of Education. Upon successful completion of the minor requirements, students are eligible for a K-12 teaching license in a foreign language. Teacher licensure candidates must apply to and be admitted to the Cato College of Education's Teacher Education Program, satisfy all requirements for admission, complete all required courses with a C or better, and pass the required state licensure exams. Teacher licensure can only be completed by students also completing a related bachelor’s degree in the target language (e.g., a French major completing the Foreign Language Education minor to be eligible for a K-12 French teaching license).

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in French is an excellent complement to any major for students interested in developing knowledge of French language and culture. Students completing the minor develop proficiency in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing in French, as well as an understanding of the diverse cultures of the French-speaking world. A minor in French will broaden a student’s career opportunities in areas such as education, international business, communications, and public service.

The minor in Geography requires 18 credit hours, 9 of which must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must choose an advising concentration, either Human Geography, Physical Geography, or Geographic Information Science. At least 6 credits of GEOG coursework must be taken at UNC Charlotte. A maximum of 6 credits from transfer coursework may be applied to the minor. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the minor is required. For more information, please see the Academic Catalog.

The Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in Geology. This minor provides students with a fundamental understanding of Earth processes, materials, and history. Students will develop skills in geological observation, analysis, and interpretation, which are valuable in various fields, including environmental science, natural resource management, and urban planning. The curriculum covers core geological concepts, including mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, stratigraphy, and paleontology.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, up to $167,000 over four years (e.g., Levine Scholars Program)

Description: The German Minor is offered by the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. A minor in German is designed for students interested in developing their proficiency in the German language and gaining a deeper understanding of German culture and society. Students will explore German literature, history, and contemporary issues, enhancing their global perspective and intercultural communication skills. This minor complements a wide range of majors, including International Business, History, Political Science, and Engineering, providing valuable language and cultural competencies for careers in various fields.

Requirements: The undergraduate minor in Gerontology requires 18 credit hours of approved coursework. The courses are interdisciplinary and students may choose a curriculum track with a focus on either social/behavioral science or health services/administration. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credit hours from the approved list of GRNT courses. Courses taken to fulfill requirements in the major can not be counted toward requirements for the minor. Students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0 to be admitted to and to graduate with the minor in Gerontology. Students interested in declaring a minor in Gerontology must meet with a Gerontology Advisor to plan their program of study and complete the "Declaration of Minor" form.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Fees: In-state: $7,336/year; Out-of-state: $22,556/year (based on 2023-2024 full-time undergraduate tuition and fees)
Description: The Gerontology Minor offers students an opportunity to study human aging. The minor is interdisciplinary and examines aging from the perspectives of sociology, psychology, public health, nursing, biology, and other fields. The minor provides a foundation for students who plan to pursue careers working with older adults, who are interested in conducting research on aging, or who are interested in further graduate study in gerontology. A minor in Gerontology provides students with the opportunity to specialize in an area of study that prepares them to address the challenges facing older adults and their families.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, and a combination of both.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Global Studies provides students with the opportunity to gain expertise in global issues and a deeper understanding of the processes of globalization. The curriculum is designed to provide students with an interdisciplinary understanding of topics such as international political economy, global development, global health, global conflict, international environmental studies, and transnational cultural movements. The minor encourages students to critically examine their own societies and cultures in relation to others, to develop an appreciation for human diversity, and to cultivate the skills necessary for responsible global citizenship.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Health Communication
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Health Communication is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of communication and health contexts as well as practical experience in both fields. Graduates will be equipped with critical skills in research, analysis, and communication that are necessary for effectively navigating the complexities of healthcare.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Health Systems Management
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Health Systems Management is offered by the Department of Public Health Sciences. The program is designed to develop students into ethical, effective and transformational leaders, managers, and problem solvers in a variety of health care organizations and agencies. The program prepares students to meet current and future challenges in the changing healthcare environment. A student graduating from this program will acquire knowledge and skills to manage, evaluate, and provide leadership to a range of health care organizations including hospitals, health care systems, managed care organizations, health insurance companies, pharmaceutical companies, long-term care facilities, consulting firms, government health agencies, and health information technology firms. Graduates are prepared for entry-level managerial positions and graduate study.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $315.91/credit hour; Non-NC Resident: $912.75/credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts vary, with scholarships like the Chancellor's Scholarship ranging from $1,000 to $4,000 annually and the Levine Scholarship covering the full cost of attendance.

Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Minor in Health Systems Management focuses on providing foundational business, organizational, and technical knowledge for students interested in careers in the growing health care industry. The minor is a collaborative effort between the Belk College of Business and the College of Health and Human Services, and is open to students in any major, especially those pursuing majors in other health care-related fields or business majors interested in the health care industry. The minor also may be of interest to pre-health students to gain a better understanding of how health care organizations are managed.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in History provides students with a broad and deep understanding of human experience in the past. It offers both chronological and geographical breadth, ensuring that students are exposed to a range of historical periods and regions. Students develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and clear communication—written and oral—that are highly valued in diverse professional fields and graduate programs. Graduates with a B.A. in History pursue careers in education, law, public service, journalism, business, archival management, and museum studies, among others.
CostPerCredit: In-state: $158.83/credit hour (tuition only); Out-of-state: $793.17/credit hour (tuition only)

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in History consists of 18 credit hours, 6 of which must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must receive a grade of “C” or better in all courses taken for the minor. No more than 6 credit hours of transfer credit may be applied to the minor. The minor in History can be a valuable complement to majors across the university, offering students a broader perspective on the issues and questions they are studying in their chosen field. The flexibility of the minor also allows students to focus on areas of particular interest to them (for example, American history, European history, or global history), or to explore a broad range of historical periods and regions. A minor in History helps students hone the analytical, research, and writing skills that are applicable to a wide variety of career paths.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $201.25/credit hour (tuition only), Out-of-State: $1,146.00/credit hour (tuition only)

ProgramName: Minor in Holocaust, Genocide, and Human Rights Studies
Requirements: Students intending to declare a Minor in Holocaust, Genocide, and Human Rights Studies must see the Program Director or the Undergraduate Coordinator in the Department of Global Studies. To be admitted to the minor, students must have a GPA of at least 2.0. The minor must be declared before the student has completed 90.0 credit hours.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Holocaust, Genocide, and Human Rights Studies provides students with a multidisciplinary understanding of the origins, dynamics, and legacies of the Holocaust and other genocides, as well as the history, theory, and practice of human rights. The minor fosters critical thinking about social, political, and historical processes leading to human rights violations and mass violence, and how such atrocities can be prevented. Students will gain knowledge of specific historical case studies as well as theoretical tools to analyze past and present patterns of human rights violations. Students will engage with historical, political, ethical, and legal aspects of the Holocaust, genocide, and human rights through different disciplinary lenses. The minor is a valuable complement to a variety of majors including Political Science, History, Religious Studies, Communication, Criminal Justice, English, International Studies, Philosophy, Social Work, and Sociology.

ProgramName: Minor in Industrial and Systems Engineering
Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Fees: In-state: $7,624/Year; Out-of-state: $38,672/Year (based on 2024-2025 full-time undergraduate rates)
Description: The minor in Industrial and Systems Engineering is for students seeking to gain foundational knowledge in the design, analysis, and improvement of complex systems. Students will learn how to apply quantitative methods to optimize processes, improve efficiency, and make data-driven decisions across various industries. This minor is suitable for students in engineering, business, computer science, and other technical fields who wish to broaden their skill set in systems thinking and operational excellence.
CollegeApplicationFee: In-state: $7,624/Year; Out-of-state: $38,672/Year (based on 2024-2025 full-time undergraduate rates)

Requirements: The minor in Information Technology is open to all University students except those in the B.S. in Computer Science, the B.S. in Cybersecurity, or the B.A. in Computer Science programs. To declare the minor, students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.5. Students must earn a grade of C or above in all courses applied to the minor.
Description: The Information Technology (IT) Minor focuses on the application, design, installation, and management of information technology resources for organizations. Topics include: database systems, networking, web development, information security, and project management. The IT Minor allows students outside of the Information Technology major to apply IT skills to their major. Students are provided with hands-on experience by completing projects which use current information technologies. The Minor provides a solid foundation for those students wishing to pursue careers in IT as well as preparing students for graduate studies in IT related fields. IT Minor coursework complements a wide range of academic majors at UNC Charlotte.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts vary; for example, the Chancellor's Scholarship is $2,000/year and the Crown Scholars Program is $3,000/year. Some prestigious programs cover full tuition.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in International Business
Requirements: UNC Charlotte practices a comprehensive and holistic review of all applications. Applicants must submit a completed application for admission, a non-refundable $80 application fee (or approved fee waiver), and an official high school transcript. The submission of official SAT or ACT scores is optional for applicants.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in International Business provides an excellent opportunity to develop the business knowledge and cross-cultural expertise needed to succeed in an increasingly globalized world. The program also integrates significant opportunities for international experience through study abroad, internships, and language immersion, fostering a deeper understanding of diverse cultures and business practices. Graduates are well-prepared to work in various international roles, including import/export, international marketing, global supply chain management, and foreign direct investment. The curriculum covers core business functions such as finance, marketing, and management, alongside specialized international business topics, including international trade, global economic environments, and cross-cultural communication.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $182.46 per credit hour; Out-of-State: $769.63 per credit hour

Description: The minor in International Studies is an interdisciplinary minor designed for students interested in a structured program of study in international topics outside their major field of study. International Studies minors develop a broader and deeper understanding of the processes of globalization; the cultural, economic, social, and political diversity of the world's peoples; and the forces driving international cooperation and conflict.

The minor in Japanese is designed to give students exposure to the Japanese language and culture. Students can complete the minor with 18 credit hours of Japanese language beyond JAPN 1202 or 15 credit hours beyond JAPN 2202. The minor is offered by the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. For more information, please contact the department.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, awards range from $1,000 to the full cost of attendance.

Requirements: The Minor in Jewish Studies requires 18 credit hours. A grade of C or above is required in all courses. At least nine (9) of the 18 credit hours for the minor must be taken in residence at UNC Charlotte. Courses for the minor cannot be taken on a Pass/No Credit basis. To declare a minor in Jewish Studies, a student should obtain a "Declaration of Minor" form from the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences Advising Center or from the Registrar's Office. This form should be completed by the student, signed by the Director of the Jewish Studies program, and submitted to the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences Advising Center.
Description: The interdisciplinary Minor in Jewish Studies offers students the opportunity to explore the rich history, culture, religion, and politics of the Jewish people. This minor provides a humanistic approach to studying Jewish civilization from ancient times to the present. The program prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as law, education, journalism, social work, public service, and the arts, or for further graduate study in related areas. A minor in Jewish Studies complements many majors offered at UNC Charlotte, including political science, history, religious studies, international studies, English, philosophy, and sociology.

Requirements: A minimum overall GPA of 2.0. A grade of C or above in COMM 2107. Students must submit an application to the Department of Communication Studies to be admitted into the minor. Students can get an application from the Communication Studies website or the departmental office.
Description: If you have an interest in a career in journalism or simply want to improve your writing and communication skills, then the Journalism minor might be for you. The minor provides students with a foundational understanding of key journalistic principles and practices including newsgathering, writing, and editing across various media platforms. Students develop a strong ethical framework, critical thinking abilities, and practical skills necessary for effective communication in a rapidly evolving media landscape. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience, preparing students for diverse roles in traditional and digital journalism, public relations, content creation, and related fields.

ProgramName: Minor in K-12 and Foreign Language Education
Requirements: Minimum GPA of 2.75. Passing scores on the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators tests (Reading, Writing, and Mathematics) or SAT/ACT equivalent scores. Oral proficiency in English demonstrated by a score of Advanced-Mid or higher on the Oral Proficiency Interview (OPI) from the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL). A grade of C or above in MFLA 2050. Students must meet with the program coordinator and submit an application for admission to the minor. To be admitted to the minor, students must complete an Application to Candidacy and submit it to the Office of Teacher Education Advising and Licensure (TEAL).
Description: The minor in K-12 and Foreign Language Education provides students with the opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of the field of foreign language education for grades K-12. The minor is a useful addition for students majoring in a foreign language such as French, German or Spanish, as well as students majoring in other fields who wish to develop knowledge and skills in foreign language teaching. The minor provides a foundation in language acquisition, second language teaching methods, and curriculum development. It is designed to prepare students for careers in foreign language education, international education, and related fields. The minor may also be helpful for students considering graduate studies in foreign language education or related fields. Students will develop an understanding of current theories and practices in foreign language education, as well as the ability to apply these theories in practical settings. The minor requires 18 credit hours, including 9 hours of core courses and 9 hours of electives.

Requirements: Students must be in good academic standing with a GPA of 2.0 or better.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: A Minor in Kinesiology provides students with a foundational understanding of the science of human movement and its application to various fields such as exercise science, sport, and health. Students will explore topics including exercise physiology, biomechanics, motor control, and health promotion, gaining insights into how physical activity impacts human performance, disease prevention, and overall well-being. This minor is suitable for students pursuing careers in healthcare, education, sports, and research, offering a valuable complement to a wide range of majors.

Requirements: This minor is open to all majors. Students should declare their intent to pursue the minor with the School of Architecture academic advisor. Students must earn a grade of C or above in all courses that apply to the Minor in Landscape Architecture.
Description: A minor in Landscape Architecture is a valuable asset for students with a wide array of majors including Architecture, Biology, Business, Civil Engineering, Computer Science, Earth Science, Environmental Studies, Geography, History, Liberal Studies, Mechanical Engineering, Political Science, Public Health, Sociology, Sustainable Technologies, Urban Studies, and others. The minor exposes students to key principles and practices in landscape architecture including cultural and natural systems, environmental design, site analysis, and graphical communication techniques. Students learn to critically evaluate landscapes, address environmental challenges, and propose design interventions that are ecologically sound, socially responsible, and aesthetically compelling. The Minor requires 18 credit hours, consisting of three core courses (9 credit hours) and three elective courses (9 credit hours) taken from a list of approved courses. The Minor is intended to provide foundational knowledge and skills in landscape architecture to students whose major is in another discipline.
Accredidation: NOT accredited by the Landscape Architectural Accreditation Board (LAAB) of the American Society of Landscape Architects (ASLA).
ScholarshipAmount: Merit scholarships range from $1,000 to full cost of attendance.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Latin American Studies minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean, including the United States as part of the Americas. Students learn about the region’s diverse cultures, histories, politics, and economies through courses in History, Political Science, Spanish, Geography, Anthropology, and other departments. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and cultural competency, preparing students for careers in fields such as international relations, education, business, journalism, and public service, as well as for graduate studies. The minor consists of 18 credit hours, including one core course and 15 elective credit hours. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credit hours at the 3000 level or above. All courses must be completed with a grade of C or better.

Requirements: Students must meet with the minor advisor before declaring the Minor in Legal Studies. To declare the minor, students must have a GPA of at least 2.0.
Description: The minor in Legal Studies is a cross-disciplinary program designed to give undergraduates a broad understanding of the nature and function of law, legal institutions, and legal processes. The minor aims to provide students with critical skills in legal analysis, reasoning, and research; to introduce students to the various roles that lawyers play in society; and to provide students with an understanding of the relationship between law and other disciplines. The minor will provide students with a solid foundation for further study in law and related fields.

The Bachelor of Science in Management degree prepares students for leadership roles in a variety of organizations across all industries. This interdisciplinary program provides students with the fundamental business and management skills required to be successful in the modern business world. Through project-based learning and experiential opportunities, students learn how to manage complex projects, lead diverse teams, foster innovation, and make effective decisions.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Management Information Systems
Description: Management Information Systems (MIS) combines the knowledge of business operations with the technical skills to design, develop, and manage information systems to improve efficiency and decision making within organizations. Students learn to analyze business problems, design appropriate technology solutions, implement and manage those solutions, and analyze data to support business decisions. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in both business and technology, preparing graduates for a variety of roles such as business analyst, systems analyst, IT consultant, database administrator, project manager, and data analyst.

Requirements: Students must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.5. Students must have completed 30 or more earned credit hours. Students must have completed INFO 2130 (or its equivalent) with a grade of C or above. Students must submit the "Declare Your Major/Minor" form to the Belk College of Business Undergraduate Programs Office.
Description: The Management Information Systems minor provides students with the fundamental concepts and techniques of management information systems. The program consists of 12 credit hours focusing on topics such as database management, business intelligence, systems analysis and design, and enterprise resource planning. The minor is suitable for students in any major seeking to enhance their knowledge and skills in the field of information systems to complement their primary area of study.

The Bachelor of Science in Marketing degree program at UNC Charlotte prepares students for careers in marketing by providing a strong business foundation and developing skills relevant to modern marketing practices. Students learn to analyze consumer behavior, develop marketing strategies, conduct market research, manage brands, and effectively communicate value to target audiences. The curriculum emphasizes both theoretical knowledge and practical application, ensuring graduates are well-equipped to meet the evolving demands of the marketing industry. Through coursework and experiential learning opportunities, students gain critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills essential for success in various marketing roles.
Accredidation: The Belk College of Business is an AACSB accredited business school. AACSB Accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education, and has been earned by less than 5 percent of the world's business programs.

Fees: In-State: $9,193.20/Year; Out-of-State: $23,703.20/Year (based on 2024-2025 rates for full-time undergraduates, includes tuition and mandatory fees)
Description: The marketing minor is designed to provide students with a fundamental understanding of marketing concepts and how they are applied in business. The courses comprising the minor provide a basic overview of marketing and then allow students to choose additional courses to deepen their understanding of particular areas in marketing, such as marketing research, digital marketing, professional selling, and advertising and promotion management. This minor is open to all students, except those majoring in marketing.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $383.06/Credit Hour; Out-of-State: $987.64/Credit Hour (based on 2024-2025 rates, includes tuition and mandatory fees)

Requirements: Our holistic review process is designed to help us get to know you as a whole person, not just your test scores or GPA. We seek to admit students who will succeed academically, get involved and enhance our vibrant campus community. A completed application includes: Application, Non-refundable application fee, Official high school transcript, and Official SAT or ACT scores (optional for 2024 admissions).
Concentration: Actuarial Science, Applied Mathematics, Mathematical Finance, Pure Mathematics, Statistics, Mathematics Teaching
Description: Mathematics provides the language and tools for understanding our world. It forms the basis for virtually all modern science and technology and is critical for understanding current public policy issues, such as health care, social security, and the environment. Mathematics majors develop analytical and problem-solving skills that are essential for successful careers in many fields. The B.S. in Mathematics is designed for students seeking a rigorous course of study with a strong emphasis in mathematics. It is particularly appropriate for students who plan to pursue graduate studies in mathematics or a related field, or who plan a career in business, industry or government where a strong mathematics background is required. The curriculum provides both a solid foundation in the core areas of mathematics and the opportunity to specialize in one of six concentrations: Actuarial Science, Applied Mathematics, Mathematical Finance, Pure Mathematics, Statistics, or Mathematics Teaching. The program will prepare graduates for successful careers as actuaries, statisticians, data scientists, financial analysts, teachers, or for graduate study.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; e.g., Johnson Scholarship is $10,000/year, Crown Scholars Program is $7,500/year. Full tuition scholarships are also available.

Requirements:
The requirements for a Minor in Mathematics are 18 credit hours of mathematics courses as specified below. A grade of C or above is required in each course counted for the minor. 

Required Courses (12 credit hours):
- MATH 1241 - Calculus I
- MATH 1242 - Calculus II
- MATH 2241 - Calculus III
- MATH 2164 - Matrices and Linear Algebra

Elective Courses (6 credit hours):
- Two additional MATH courses at the 3000-level or above.
Description: The Minor in Mathematics is designed for students who are pursuing a major other than Mathematics but wish to supplement their education with a strong background in mathematics. The minor provides students with a solid foundation in calculus, linear algebra, and differential equations, as well as an opportunity to explore advanced topics such as abstract algebra, real analysis, and probability and statistics. The program emphasizes problem-solving skills, critical thinking, and logical reasoning, preparing students for careers in various fields, including science, engineering, technology, finance, and education. The minor also serves as an excellent preparation for graduate studies in mathematics or related disciplines.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $311.76/credit hour; Non-NC Resident: $926.96/credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: $3,000/year to full cost of attendance

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering
Requirements: For first-year admission, applicants must submit a completed application and fee, an official high school transcript, and standardized test scores (SAT/ACT). However, UNC Charlotte is test-optional for students applying for admission through Fall 2024. A personal essay is a recommended component of the application.
Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: Mechanical engineers are involved in the design and manufacture of almost everything. They work in areas such as energy (gas, steam, nuclear, solar), aerospace (airframes, jet engines, rockets), automotive (engines, chassis, safety), manufacturing (robotics, control, automation), and bioengineering (prosthetics, medical devices). Our curriculum provides a thorough preparation for professional practice in mechanical engineering. It includes courses in mechanical system design, solid mechanics, thermal-fluid sciences, control systems, and mechanical behavior of materials. Graduates are prepared for careers in industry or for advanced study at the graduate level.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: The Mechanical Engineering Minor offers students pursuing other majors the opportunity to gain fundamental knowledge in mechanical engineering principles and applications. The minor complements various technical fields, providing students with a broader skill set and enhancing their career prospects. Students will gain an understanding of mechanics, thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and materials science, preparing them for diverse challenges in industry or further academic pursuits.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Middle Grades Education
Requirements: UNC Charlotte practices a comprehensive and holistic review process that considers the following: rigor of academic coursework, academic performance (GPA), and extracurricular activities (leadership, service, work experience, etc.). An essay is also required as part of the application.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Middle Grades Education prepares students to teach in grades six through nine. Students in the Middle Grades program specialize in two content areas (English, Mathematics, Science, or Social Studies). Upon graduation and successful completion of the North Carolina Foundations of Reading and General Curriculum tests, students are eligible for a North Carolina teaching license in their two chosen content areas for grades 6-9.

Requirements: The minor in Military Science is open to all University students in good academic standing who are U.S. citizens and meet the physical standards for admission to the Basic Course.
Description: The minor in Military Science is designed to prepare students for leadership positions in the US Army. Army ROTC (Reserve Officers’ Training Corps) is an elective curriculum you take along with your required college courses. It gives you the tools to become an officer in the U.S. Army, Army Reserve, or Army National Guard. ROTC provides leadership training, scholarship opportunities, and the chance to serve your country after graduation. The Military Science minor is offered by the Department of Military Science.
ScholarshipAmount: Army ROTC scholarships can provide full tuition and fees OR $10,000 per year for room and board, plus a $1,200 annual book allowance and a $420 monthly stipend.
ScholarshipPercentage: Up to 100% of tuition and fees

Requirements: A student wishing to declare a Minor in Music must meet with a music advisor in the Department of Music. The minor is available to any student who meets the general requirements for a minor.
Description: The Music minor is intended for students who wish to pursue their interest in music while majoring in another field. The Music minor introduces students to the foundations of music study through coursework in music theory, history, and ensemble performance. Students gain a broad understanding of musical concepts, historical periods, and performance practices. This minor complements a wide range of majors, providing a valuable asset for careers in arts management, education, therapy, and other fields that benefit from a strong musical background.

Requirements: Admission to the Department of Music requires an audition for the department in addition to the application to the University. General university application requirements include an application form, an application fee, and an official high school transcript. Submission of SAT or ACT scores is optional. The personal essay is a recommended item. The supplemental application to the Department of Music requires a music résumé.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Music provides students with a broad and flexible music education that prepares them for a variety of careers and graduate study. Students gain a thorough understanding of music theory, history, and performance practices through a rigorous curriculum that balances academic coursework with practical experience. The program emphasizes critical thinking, creativity, and cultural awareness, allowing them to explore diverse musical traditions and develop their individual artistic voices. Graduates are equipped with the skills and knowledge necessary to pursue careers in music education, performance, composition, arts administration, music therapy, and other related fields, or to continue their studies in graduate programs.
Accredidation: Accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Music in Music Education
Requirements: Admission to the Department of Music is a dual-admission process. Students are required to be admitted to both the University and the Department of Music. Acceptance by the University does not guarantee acceptance by the department. Auditions and interviews are required for all students seeking admission as majors and minors in the Department of Music.
Description: The Bachelor of Music in Music Education degree prepares students to be exemplary music teachers in public and private schools. Students are educated as performing musicians and pedagogues in a comprehensive approach to music education. Students choose a K-12 choral or K-12 instrumental concentration. This program leads to initial licensure in North Carolina. UNC Charlotte is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM).
Accredidation: Accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Music in Music Performance
Requirements:
All prospective music majors and minors must complete a two-part application process:

1. Apply to UNC Charlotte by the admissions deadlines.
2. Apply to the Department of Music. This involves submitting an online music application and scheduling an audition.

You must be accepted by both the University and the Department of Music to become a music major or minor.
Description: The Bachelor of Music in Music Performance provides intensive musical training for students pursuing careers as professional performers or private teachers. The degree focuses on performance mastery, providing students with individual instruction, performance opportunities, and in-depth study of repertoire and theory. Students pursue a broad range of core music courses, including music theory, ear training, music history, and keyboard skills. Performance majors also participate in weekly private lessons, masterclasses, and music ensembles. The program prepares students for graduate study in performance or for careers in a variety of musical professions including orchestral playing, chamber music, freelancing, and private teaching.
Accredidation: The Department of Music is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM).

Requirements: Admission to the BSN program is a two-phase process. Phase I is admission to the University as a Pre-Nursing Student through the University Office of Undergraduate Admissions. General first-year application requirements include an online application and fee, official high school transcript, and a short essay. Standardized test scores (SAT/ACT) are optional. Phase II is the competitive application to the Upper Division of the nursing program. Requirements for the Upper Division application include completion of a separate School of Nursing application, completion of a minimum of 45 of the 59 required lower division semester hours, a minimum GPA of 3.0 in all lower division coursework, successful completion of the Test of Essential Academic Skills (TEAS), and completion of Certified Nurse Aide (CNA I) training and listing on a state registry.
Department: School of Nursing, College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.S.N.) prepares students for roles as professional nurses. Graduates are eligible to apply to take the National Council Licensure Examination for Registered Nurses (NCLEX-RN) and pursue graduate education in nursing. The School of Nursing offers the following program options: Traditional Pre-licensure B.S.N. Program, Accelerated Pre-licensure B.S.N. Program, R.N. to B.S.N. Program, Veteran’s B.S.N. Program. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, clinical judgment, evidence-based practice, and leadership skills essential for providing high-quality, patient-centered care in diverse healthcare settings. Students gain hands-on experience through clinical rotations in various specialties, including medical-surgical, pediatrics, obstetrics, psychiatric/mental health, and community health. The program fosters a commitment to lifelong learning, professional development, and advocacy for individuals, families, and communities.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE)
CollegeApplicationFee: $800 per semester (Special Program Fee for Upper Division)
ScholarshipAmount: Varies

Requirements: In order to complete your application, you must submit the following: Online Application; $80 Application Fee; Official High School Transcript; SAT or ACT Scores. We also require an essay as a part of the application for admission.
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Physics degree program at UNC Charlotte provides students with a strong foundation in classical and modern physics, as well as hands-on experience in laboratory techniques and computational methods. Our curriculum is designed to prepare students for a wide range of careers in industry, government, and academia, or for further graduate studies in physics or related fields. Students will develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, as well as a deep understanding of the fundamental principles that govern the universe. The program also offers optional concentrations in Applied Physics, Computational Physics, and Physics Education, allowing students to specialize their studies based on their interests and career goals.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with several scholarships ranging from $2,000-$5,000 per year and some covering the full cost of attendance.

Description: A minor in physics consists of 19 semester hours of coursework chosen in consultation with the Department of Physics and Optical Science minor advisor. These hours must include PHYS 2101, PHYS 2102, PHYS 2101L, and PHYS 2102L. The remaining nine hours of coursework must be taken from 3000- and 4000-level PHYS courses. At least 6 hours must be completed at UNC Charlotte. If you are interested in a career in physics, or if you are considering applying for graduate school, the Minor in Physics is an excellent option to complement your undergraduate major. Your coursework will provide a solid background in the foundations of physics, including classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, waves, optics, and modern physics. You will also develop strong problem-solving and analytical skills that are highly valued in a variety of fields.
ScholarshipAmount: $1,000 - $6,000 annually, with premier awards covering full cost of attendance.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: Political Science is concerned with how human beings govern themselves at local, national, and international levels. Students learn about the role of government, voting and elections, political parties, interest groups, the formation and implementation of public policy, and the causes of conflict and cooperation among nations. Through a major in Political Science, students develop skills in critical thinking, research, writing, and analysis. In addition, students gain understanding of the structures and processes of political institutions and an appreciation for differing political viewpoints. The department offers concentrations in International Relations, Pre-Law, and Public Policy for students who wish to focus their studies. Students are encouraged to pursue internships and study abroad opportunities.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; ranges from small amounts to full cost of attendance (e.g., Levine Scholars Program).

Requirements: At least 18 credit hours of POLS courses are required for the minor. A grade of C or above is required in each course counted toward the minor. At least half of the credit hours for the minor must be completed at UNC Charlotte. No more than two transfer courses (six credit hours) may be counted toward the minor. No course taken on a Pass/No Credit basis may be included in the minor.
Description: Political science is the study of governments, public policies, political processes, and political behavior. The minor in Political Science is an excellent option for students seeking to add breadth to their primary course of study. A minor in political science will allow students to deepen their understanding of political processes in the United States and abroad and to analyze political issues across different subfields.

Psychology is the scientific study of the mind and behavior. Psychology as a discipline and profession is broad and diverse, encompassing a variety of specialties that reflect the complexity of behavior and mental processes. The goal of the Psychology major is to provide a broad understanding of the scientific nature of Psychology, its historical roots, and its applications. Our faculty are active researchers, and provide students opportunities to get involved in research early in their academic careers.
The Bachelor of Arts in Psychology prepares students for entry-level positions in a number of fields, including human services, education, and business, or to pursue graduate study in psychology or other disciplines. Our graduates are competitive for admission to graduate programs in areas such as clinical psychology, social psychology, neuroscience, cognitive psychology, human factors psychology, forensic psychology, and school psychology. In addition, the B.A. in Psychology provides an excellent foundation for professional degrees in law, medicine, or other health-related professions. The Psychology B.A. curriculum provides a solid foundation of coursework in core areas of the discipline. Students are also able to choose additional courses that reflect their interests.
A Bachelor of Arts degree provides an excellent foundation for a variety of careers. The specific courses and experiences of the program help students develop skills in critical thinking, problem-solving, research methods, statistical analysis, and written and oral communication. Many of our students gain valuable experience in research labs, teaching assistantships, and community internships.
Students can meet with the Chief Departmental Advisor and/or the Pre-Graduate School Advisor to discuss appropriate course selection based on their career aspirations. The Department also houses a chapter of Psi Chi, the National Honor Society in Psychology, which provides opportunities for social and professional development. In addition, the Psychology Club is open to all students and organizes activities throughout the year.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $184.04/credit hour; Non-NC Resident: $833.92/credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: $1,500 - $6,000 annually for merit scholarships; up to full tuition for premier programs

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Public Health
Requirements: Students can declare a major in public health when they apply for admission to UNC Charlotte as first-year or transfer students. Current UNC Charlotte students can declare a major in public health if they have earned a minimum of 12 credit hours and have a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Public Health (BSPH) prepares students for a variety of careers in health education, health promotion, disease prevention, and public health practice. Students in the program develop the knowledge and skills necessary to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate public health programs. You will choose a concentration in one of two areas: Community Health or Health Informatics and Analytics. Graduates of the BSPH program are eligible to sit for the Certified Health Education Specialist (CHES) exam and are prepared for a variety of entry-level positions in local, state, and national health departments, non-profit organizations, hospitals, government agencies, and corporations. The program also provides a strong foundation for graduate study in public health or other health-related fields.

Department: College of Health and Human Services
Fees: NC Resident: $4,438.50/semester; Non-NC Resident: $11,922.00/semester (for full-time undergraduates)
Description: A minor in Public Health is an excellent complement to many majors across campus. It helps students understand the complex issues that impact the health of populations in the U.S. and around the world. The Minor in Public Health will introduce students to the key public health concepts and core public health disciplines that prevent disease and promote health. Students will learn how to improve the health of individuals, communities, and populations through interdisciplinary coursework that emphasizes health promotion, prevention, health disparities, and global health. Required courses include an introductory public health course and a senior seminar with the remaining courses chosen from a list of approved public health electives. Students must earn a grade of C or better in all courses to count toward the minor.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $739.75/credit hour; Non-NC Resident: $1,993.00/credit hour (includes fees for on-campus students)
CollegeApplicationFee: NC Resident: $4,438.50/semester; Non-NC Resident: $11,922.00/semester (for full-time undergraduates)

Description: The minor in Reading Education at UNC Charlotte is designed for undergraduate students interested in developing knowledge and skills in the area of literacy education. It is open to any student pursuing a bachelor's degree at UNC Charlotte, and is especially beneficial for those interested in pursuing a career in education in public, private, or charter schools. The minor may also be beneficial for those interested in working with children and/or adults in a variety of non-school settings. Successful completion of the minor will provide students with specialized knowledge of literacy development, instruction, and assessment across diverse settings and learners.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Religious Studies
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Religious Studies provides students with a broad and deep understanding of religious phenomena, practices, and traditions across diverse cultures and historical periods. This degree is designed for students interested in a more interdisciplinary and social scientific approach to the study of religion. The B.S. curriculum focuses on methods of empirical research and critical analysis, preparing students for careers in fields such as social work, counseling, public service, non-profit organizations, and advanced study in social sciences. Graduates will develop strong analytical, research, and communication skills applicable to a wide range of professional and academic pursuits.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $317.67/Credit Hour, Non-NC Resident: $1511.33/Credit Hour

Requirements: To declare a Minor in Religious Studies, please go to the department office in Fretwell 230 and fill out the form.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in Religious Studies offers students an opportunity to explore the various expressions of human religious experience from a broad, interdisciplinary perspective. This minor complements a wide variety of majors by introducing students to the academic study of religion while honing their critical thinking, reading, and writing skills. Students gain a greater appreciation for the ways in which religious traditions and practices both reflect and shape cultural, political, economic, and historical forces, both locally and globally. The minor requires 18 credit hours across multiple traditions and methods in religious studies. This minor can provide excellent preparation for careers in law, medicine, education, public service, international relations, journalism, social work, and the arts, among others.

Requirements: The Minor in Russian Studies consists of 18 credit hours beyond the 1202 level. All minors must complete RUSS 2210 and RUSS 2211 or the equivalent. The remaining 12 hours may include courses in Russian at the 2000 level and above, and related courses offered in other departments (when a substantial portion of the work is devoted to Russian and/or East European topics). A grade of C or above is required in all courses counting toward the minor. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credit hours at UNC Charlotte.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in Russian studies provides students with an understanding of Russian language, culture, and society. The Russian minor prepares students for a variety of professions that involve international affairs, business, government, and education while encouraging students to think critically about Russian history, literature, and current events. The minor consists of 18 credit hours, including nine credit hours in Russian language and nine credit hours in Russian culture and civilization. Students must complete Russian 2201 and 2202, or the equivalent, or have permission from the Russian advisor. Students are encouraged to study abroad in Russia to gain immersive language and cultural experience.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Secondary Education
Concentration: Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, English, History, Mathematics, Physics, Social Studies, Spanish
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Secondary Education prepares future middle and high school teachers in a variety of content areas. Students acquire skills and knowledge in teaching methods, curriculum development, and classroom management, as well as a deep understanding of adolescent development and diverse learners. The program integrates extensive field experiences, culminating in a semester-long student teaching internship, ensuring graduates are well-prepared to meet the demands of today's secondary classrooms. Upon successful completion, graduates are eligible for North Carolina teaching licensure in their chosen subject area.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
ScholarshipAmount: up to $8,000 per year

Description: The Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) Program at UNC Charlotte prepares students for generalist social work practice with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities. The program emphasizes a global perspective and provides students with skills in critical thinking, advocacy, and ethical decision-making. Students learn how to assess needs, plan and implement interventions, and evaluate outcomes, all while adhering to the core values of the social work profession. With a strong foundation in both theory and practice, graduates are equipped to address complex social issues and promote social justice in diverse settings.
Accredidation: Fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

Department: College of Health and Human Services
Fees: In-state: $7,842/year; Out-of-state: $23,072/year (based on 2024-2025 rates for full-time undergraduate students)
Description: The Minor in Social Work is designed for students from other disciplines who desire to learn more about social work issues, social problems, and social welfare in contemporary society. The minor in social work does not prepare students for social work practice, but it does provide students with a general knowledge base about social work as a profession, social problems, and social service organizations and programs.
CostPerCredit: In-state: $326.76/credit hour; Out-of-state: $961.34/credit hour (based on 2024-2025 rates)

Requirements: Admission to UNC Charlotte is based on a holistic review. A complete first-year application requires a completed online application, a non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. For spring 2024, fall 2024, and spring 2025 admission, first-year students have the option to have their application reviewed with or without standardized test scores (SAT or ACT). It is also highly recommended, though not required, to submit a personal essay and a list of extracurricular activities or a resume to strengthen the application.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Sociology program provides students with a strong foundation in sociological theory, research methods, and data analysis. Students develop a critical understanding of social structures, institutions, and interactions, exploring topics such as inequality, race and ethnicity, gender, family, religion, education, health, and crime. The curriculum emphasizes analytical thinking, problem-solving, and effective communication skills, preparing graduates for a wide range of careers in social services, public policy, research, advocacy, and business, or for further graduate studies.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; amounts range from $5,000/year to the full cost of attendance.

Description: The minor in Sociology consists of 18 credit hours of Sociology courses at the 2000-level or above. All students completing a minor in Sociology must take SOCY 2101 or SOCY 2103 (whichever is appropriate to the student's major) and SOCY 2160, and 12 additional credit hours in Sociology courses at the 3000-level or above, with at least one course at the 4000-level. All minor courses must be completed with a grade of C or above. For more information, please see the Undergraduate Catalog.

ProgramName: Minor in Software and Information Systems
Description: The minor in Software and Information Systems is designed to provide undergraduate students with a solid foundation in the principles and practices of software development and information systems management. This minor is suitable for students from various disciplines who wish to enhance their understanding of how software systems are designed, developed, and managed, and how information systems support organizational objectives. Students will gain practical skills in programming, database management, web development, and system analysis, preparing them for a wide range of career opportunities in technology-driven fields or for further study in software and information systems.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Spanish must have a GPA of 2.0. The minor must be declared before the student has completed 90 hours of coursework. Minors may not be declared by students with senior standing. Minors are declared online.
Description: The Spanish minor at UNC Charlotte is designed to provide students with an understanding of Spanish language and the cultures of Spanish-speaking communities through a sequence of courses beyond the intermediate level. Students develop competency in reading, writing, listening, and speaking, along with an understanding of Hispanic cultures, literatures, and linguistics. This minor is an excellent complement to many majors, including International Studies, Political Science, Global Studies, Criminal Justice, Education, Communication, and Business, as it enhances students’ career opportunities in a variety of fields requiring intercultural communication and knowledge of world languages and cultures.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Special Education
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Special Education is an undergraduate program designed to prepare candidates to work with students with disabilities in K-12 public school settings. The program is specifically structured to meet the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction licensure requirements for both general curriculum and adapted curriculum teacher licensure. The coursework provides students with a strong foundation in evidence-based practices for teaching students with disabilities, behavior management, assessment, and collaboration with families and other professionals. Students complete extensive field experiences in K-12 settings throughout their program of study, culminating in a full-time student teaching internship. Upon successful completion of the program, candidates are eligible for initial North Carolina teacher licensure in Special Education: General Curriculum (K-12) or Special Education: Adapted Curriculum (K-12).

Requirements: First-year applicants must submit an online application, a non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. Official college transcripts are required if any college coursework has been completed. The submission of SAT or ACT scores is optional.
Description: Statistics is the science of collecting, organizing, analyzing, and interpreting data, as well as drawing conclusions and making decisions based on data. The B.S. in Statistics program provides students with a solid foundation in both the theory and application of statistics and data science. The program focuses on statistical methodology including areas such as regression analysis, experimental design, and statistical inference. Graduates with a B.S. in Statistics will be prepared for a wide variety of career options in industry, government, and non-profit organizations where quantitative skills are highly valued. These careers include roles such as data analyst, statistician, data scientist, business intelligence analyst, and quantitative analyst. Additionally, the B.S. in Statistics provides excellent preparation for graduate study in statistics, biostatistics, data science, and related quantitative fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; awards range from $2,000 annually to full cost of attendance.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Statistics must have a grade of C or above in either STAT 1220, STAT 1221, or STAT 1222 and an overall GPA of 2.0 or above. Students who do not meet these requirements can seek an exception from the department.
Description: A minor in Statistics will enhance your academic profile and add value to your degree regardless of your major. Statistics is the science of learning from data. Statisticians are problem solvers who work in a variety of industries, including health care, manufacturing, and financial services. Statisticians are in demand because they are experts in data analysis. They interpret data, make predictions, and discover patterns, so they are essential to every organization. The Department of Mathematics and Statistics in the College of Computing and Informatics offers the Minor in Statistics.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; e.g., Chancellor's Scholarship at $5,000/year, Johnson Scholarship at $2,000/year

Requirements: The Minor in Systems Engineering requires 18 credit hours. A grade of C or above is required in all courses for the Minor. Required Courses (12 credit hours): SEGR 2100 - Introduction to Systems Engineering (3), SEGR 2200 - Systems Engineering Design Tools I (3), SEGR 3100 - Systems Engineering Design Tools II (3), SEGR 3200 - Systems Engineering Design Project (3). Electives (6 credit hours): Choose 6 credit hours from the following: SEGR 4991 - Systems Engineering Topics (3), SEGR 4992 - Systems Engineering Topics (3), SEGR 4993 - Systems Engineering Topics (3), SEGR 4994 - Systems Engineering Topics (3), SEGR 4995 - Systems Engineering Topics (3).
Department: William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: The Systems Engineering Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge in Systems Engineering to complement their undergraduate degree and broaden their career options. Systems Engineering focuses on designing, integrating, and managing complex systems over their entire life cycles. Students who complete the Minor in Systems Engineering will acquire knowledge and skills in systems engineering methodologies, modeling, analysis, and management. This minor is open to all students, but is particularly beneficial to engineering and computer science students. The minor can be completed with five courses or 15 credits.

The Bachelor of Arts in Theatre is a liberal arts degree providing a broad foundation in theatre arts and studies within the context of a strong liberal arts education. Students receive significant training in their chosen area of concentration, which includes Acting, Design and Technology, Musical Theatre, Stage Management, Theatre Education (K-12), Theatre Studies, and Theatre for Youth. Students pursuing the B.A. in Theatre will become effective communicators, collaborators, critical thinkers, and creative problem solvers. Theatre majors enjoy numerous opportunities for artistic and technical growth and for developing leadership skills. A wide array of practicum courses and internships are available in the department and in the vibrant Charlotte professional theatre community. The program provides an excellent foundation for students desiring to pursue graduate work in theatre or to pursue professional careers in the performing arts. Many of our graduates pursue careers beyond the arts in fields that value creative problem solving, communication, collaboration, and critical thinking. The B.A. in Theatre is offered through the Department of Theatre in the College of Arts + Architecture.

Requirements: Students wishing to declare a Minor in Theatre should contact the Department of Theatre Undergraduate Coordinator. An advising appointment is required prior to the declaration of the Minor. A grade of C or above is required in all courses for the Minor in Theatre.
Description: The Minor in Theatre provides students with the opportunity to deepen their understanding of and appreciation for theatre. Students take courses in three areas: Dramatic Literature/History/Criticism, Performance, and Production. This minor is open to all students, regardless of their major, and encourages them to explore the various facets of theatre, including acting, directing, design, stagecraft, playwriting, and theatre history. The Minor in Theatre provides a creative outlet for students while complementing a variety of majors.

The Urban Studies Minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the physical, social, economic, and political forces that shape metropolitan areas and their surrounding environments. The minor will help students analyze these forces using a variety of social science theories and methods. Coursework involves a combination of required and elective courses, allowing students to focus on areas of particular interest. Graduates with a minor in Urban Studies will be well-prepared for careers in fields such as urban planning, public administration, community development, nonprofit management, and real estate, or for graduate study in related disciplines.

ProgramName: Minor in Women's and Gender Studies
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Women's and Gender Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the social construction of gender and the roles gender plays in shaping social relationships and individual experiences. The curriculum draws on scholarship from across the humanities and social sciences to explore topics such as feminist theories, LGBTQ+ studies, gender and sexuality, race and ethnicity, social justice, and global women's issues. Students develop analytical skills and a nuanced perspective on gender in various contexts, preparing them for diverse careers and further academic pursuits. The minor complements a wide range of majors by providing valuable insights into power dynamics, social inequalities, and cultural representations related to gender, enhancing students' critical thinking and research abilities.
